reviews.text: The makeup effects are believable, the film does not overuse cartoonish digital effects, and Wan's direction manages to develop a thick, dense atmosphere that compensates for some of the script's flaws. Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: After years of lackluster releases from major studios, The Conjuring goes back to basics and manages to make something much more effective out of its formulaic story. It doesn't reinvent the wheel in any major way, but still largely thrilling.
reviews.author: Patrick Cavanaugh

reviews.text: If we're really going to depart from the known horror of the first decade of the century... instead of conditioning emotions so crudely, we have to give the public a real point of view. So far Wan doesn't have it. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Erick Estrada

reviews.text: Ten years later, The Conjuring is still one of the best horror films.
reviews.author: Sara Clements

reviews.text: Perhaps Wan's biggest achievement is that when the traditional sequel setup is revealed, the overall feeling is one of anticipation, rather than the sadly familiar dread.
reviews.author: James Croot

reviews.text: What’s special about The Conjuring is how well director James Wan controls this environment. He uses the setting like a filmic funhouse ride spring-loaded with precisely timed jolts and screams.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: As someone a little tired of the bland, run-of-the-mill “horror” we get today, I was a bit skeptical. But I love being surprised and this film did that for me.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: The scares are built up more through quiet tension that is commendably shot and executed and a nice atmosphere is created that helps to present a very unnerving tone.
reviews.author: Josh Parham

reviews.text: Remarkably retro yet effective in its chills and thrills.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: If you're looking for some really good scares, The Conjuring is what you want.
reviews.author: Damond Fudge

reviews.text: "The Conjuring," takes pages from two of our favorite subgenres-the haunted house and the exorcism-and combines them to great effect to tell a purportedly true tale of real life terror.
reviews.author: Brent McKnight

reviews.text: Horror junkies will find 'life after death' when watching 'The Conjuring', a dark, overwhelming and chilling film that constantly shoots fear to entertain. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yasser Medina

reviews.text: Fans of James Wan's previous output, or fans of haunted tales of abject terror, will find a lot to love in The Conjuring, even if it ultimately falls short of "all time great" status in a busy and convoluted climax.
reviews.author: Ed Travis

reviews.text: This decade's definitive horror classic.
reviews.author: Karl Delossantos

reviews.text: You won't see a better crafted creepathon come out of the studios anytime soon.
reviews.author: Nicholas Bell

reviews.text: Perhaps what gives The Conjuring its pulse is the decision to tell the story from the point of view of the investigators -- giving the film a much-needed human layer.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: seems like James Wan has found his official ghost movie shooting style, because ... I feel like this film is almost indistinguishable from Insidious.
reviews.author: Amie Simon

reviews.text: The back half of the movie is also more formulaic and less interesting in every other way. The characters no longer offer surprises, and the scares are more predictable.
reviews.author: Eve Tushnet

reviews.text: On balance, though, The Conjuring is an effective horror tale, with a couple of gut-punch moments, and that's more than can be said of many other genre offerings.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: This film surpasses the best of the movie franchise in its ability to unnerve audiences in a uniquely skillful and spine-chilling approach to the haunted house narrative.
reviews.author: Sarah Gopaul

reviews.text: There's nothing terribly new about Australian director James Wan's sixth film-it's just a testament to good scares.
reviews.author: Sean Fennessey

reviews.text: The Conjuring lives up to the marketing and hype, it is easily one of the best horror films so far this year.
reviews.author: Aaron Peterson

reviews.text: One of the first films in years where I was legit scared.
reviews.author: Funmi Sunmonu

reviews.text: Traditional tropes are as fresh as ever in what is an unnerving, albeit kitsch horror of remarkable finesse.
reviews.author: Joseph Walsh

reviews.text: Wonderful dark elements and a pretty tight script, it's definitely worth the watch, horror fan or not.
reviews.author: Mae Abdulbaki

reviews.text: A great antidote to your standard dehumanizing horror movie.
reviews.author: Charlie Jane Anders

reviews.text: The film is blood-chilling and easily as terrifying, if not more so, than classic '70s horrors like The Exorcist.
reviews.author: Megan Basham

reviews.text: Whilst all films of this nature have some element of predictability, The Conjuring manages to keep things fresh and the viewer on the edge of their seat.
reviews.author: Andrew Pollard

reviews.text: The Conjuring is an especially well-crafted horror movie made almost entirely from practical effects, which is increasingly refreshing to see.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: The Conjuring is a throwback to classic 1970s horror, the heyday of possession, if you will.
reviews.author: Dorothy Woodend

reviews.text: The Conjuring is a memorably spooky event; a campfire tale told with a breathless adamancy that stirs the hackles and attacks the imagination.
reviews.author: Nathan Bartlebaugh

reviews.text: This is no classic, but director James Wan is a deft conductor who orchestrates the scariest ride of the season from threads of familiarly black melodies.
reviews.author: Kong Rithdee

reviews.text: At best, "The Conjuring" is a drop or two of rain in the middle of a decades-long horror drought. It won't tide anyone over for more than a couple hours.
reviews.author: J. Olson

reviews.text: A movie that exemplifies the golden standards of the haunted house formula and escalates them to something rather rousing.
reviews.author: David Keyes

reviews.text: By all means, feel free to initially underrate this finely crafted and genuinely scary production. Making such a mistake will only serve to leave you more impressed (and slightly rattled) than you might have been.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: An old-fashioned haunted house horror story made by people who love them. Classy, creepy, fun.
reviews.author: Scott Weinberg

reviews.text: The sound design of the movie is oppressive beyond belief -- this damn thing is louder than "Pacific Rim."
reviews.author: Rob Gonsalves

reviews.text: The Conjuring's use of tension, atmosphere, and suggestion prove that the scariest thing to an audience has nothing to do with what you see, but what you don't.
reviews.author: Chris Stuckmann

reviews.text: Wan uses every horror cliche with blithe confidence. He knows no one is immune if the effects are sturdily built, and not too literal.
reviews.author: Paul Byrnes

reviews.text: Sometimes it all comes down to craftsmanship. There's probably nothing you haven't seen before in director James Wan's The Conjuring, but rarely have you seen it done so well.
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: The Conjuring simply takes a standard story comprised of the usual components, and with warmth and commitment makes them not just palatable, but successful.
reviews.author: Sarah Ward

reviews.text: It's solidly effective at bringing the scares, which is all it really sets out to do, right?
reviews.author: Brad Keefe

reviews.text: The viewer is completely absorbed in a story peppered with genuine, unexpected, bump in the night scares that will keep you on the edge of your seat.
reviews.author: Whitney Scott Bain

reviews.text: The trailer for The Conjuring is scarier than most horror features of recent vintage, and the feature makes good on the promise.
reviews.author: Scott Marks

reviews.text: Fans of old-school scary movies and J-horror, rejoice. James Wan's The Conjuring is going to scare the bejeezus out of you.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: Mainly, the movie wants to scare us, and it succeeds.
reviews.author: Jesse Hassenger

reviews.text: Wan is basically just remaking his own Insidious with a few modest tweaks and a polyester wardrobe, and, just like that movie, The Conjuring gets progressively less scary as it goes along.
reviews.author: Norman Wilner

reviews.text: This one never really takes hold and goes horribly wrong about 20 minutes before the end.
reviews.author: Evan Williams

reviews.text: An Overlook Hotel-sized creepshow that is genuinely frightening.
reviews.author: Richard Knight

reviews.text: Leaving slashers behind for the murky uncertainties of the supernatural, James Wan has found a way to expand his talents while driving yet another modern genre shift.
reviews.author: Bryan Bishop

reviews.text: Every hand that reaches into a wardrobe, every nervous trip into that basement just gets on your nerves. Satan needs to get over himself.
reviews.author: Wesley Morris

reviews.text: Director James Wan delivers effective scares, showing more interest in sinewy camera moves and building a slow creep than in mindless gore, but the performances are a mixed bag, and the script repeatedly seeks refuge in the familiar.
reviews.author: Daniel Barnes

reviews.text: Advance word that this would be the scariest horror since Amityville proves well wide of the mark.
reviews.author: Anthony Quinn

reviews.text: Despite having a fairly standard haunted house horror plot, James Wan has created a fun, scary and beautiful looking movie.
reviews.author: Alicia Malone

reviews.text: It is scary, and it conveys something even rarer in horror films -- the ring of truth.
reviews.author: Christopher Tookey

reviews.text: A strong cast and an atmosphere of real dread mean that despite a catalogue of immediately recognisable ghost devices, The Conjuring amounts to more than the sum of its scary parts.
reviews.author: Owen Williams

reviews.text: There's nothing new or original about it, but it's entertaining enough, and one can't help but respect the craft that went into making something catchy out of component parts stolen from others.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: [Wan] combines the ambiance of horror's leisure-suit heyday with the more recent brand of well-timed what's-that-in-the-mirror scares.
reviews.author: Sarah Mankoff

reviews.text: It's atmospheric, terrifying, and brilliant in its intricately placed bouts of horror and suspense.
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: Director James Wan, best known for creating the Saw franchise, delivers his finest work to date. Instead of relying on the graphic, slasher-style techniques that made Saw a hit, Wan turns to old-fashioned suspense, and the payoff is big.
reviews.author: Forrest Hartman

reviews.text: Better-than-average demon movie goes bump in the night
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: In The Conjuring, the scary casts out the spirit of the silly, permanently, and with a vengeance.
reviews.author: Michael O'Sullivan

reviews.text: The Conjuring is a well-crafted throwback to old school horror films, and the scares are unrelenting, but fans of the genre may find themselves guessing what is coming next.
reviews.author: Allison Loring

reviews.text: Easily one of the best horror films I've seen in years.
reviews.author: Luke Mullen

reviews.text: Even in the dark, it's clear where this is going -- but Wan does know his way around a haunted house.
reviews.author: Alan Jones

reviews.text: With any luck, The Conjuring will lead potential future horror filmmakers raised on a diet of torture porn and slasher films to rethink their approach. One can hope, at least.
reviews.author: David Medsker

reviews.text: The Conjuring uses every stock scare in the horror movie playbook for a dumb, yet charmingly traditional haunted house picture that manages to feel more retro than rehashed.
reviews.author: Phil Brown

reviews.text: Wan takes some unpromising ingredients and cooks it with style, tension and heart-stopping surprise moments.
reviews.author: Jim Slotek

reviews.text: A carefully, masterfully crafted and ever-so-crescendoing exercise in atmospheric dread.
reviews.author: Michael Dequina

reviews.text: These things run on faith, not reason, like the silly amateur exorcism that will have to be intoned when a priest is too far away and the silly scientific paraphernalia carted around.
reviews.author: Donald J. Levit

reviews.text: The Conjuring is the Ultimate Fighting Champion of haunting movies. It is all of the movies. Every single one.
reviews.author: Glenn Dunks

reviews.text: A very effectively mounted frightfest, played extremely straight, with very good performances.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: A pastiche of every horror movie you've ever seen but one that is enlivened by the screenplay written by the twin brothers who wrote the superlative 2006 remake of "House of Wax".
reviews.author: Louis Proyect

reviews.text: None of it is particularly bloody or violent, but young Wan and twin screenwriters Chad and Carey Hayes, up to now mostly unheralded in the horror genre, fashion a harrowing montage of thrills from beginning to end.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: America's stealth auteur, James Wan, directs unpretentious, inexpensive, stylistically consistent horror movies that spook audiences and scare up enormous profits; he embraces the genre's tropes and demonstrates why they continue to unnerve.
reviews.author: John Beifuss

reviews.text: As a solid spook show, The Conjuring works, though the ending doesn't strike me as big enough for the story leading up to it.
reviews.author: Ken Hanke

reviews.text: The Conjuring suffers from a lack of momentum that proves impossible to overlook...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: I was not expecting to be scared out of my wits by this creepily crafted and sublimely superior supernatural horror, but I was. Before the end, my cinema seat had worked itself through the three demonic stages of infestation, oppression and possession.
reviews.author: Brian Henry Martin

reviews.text: It's scare-to-medium stuff with the usual ghoulies, ghosties, long-leggedy beasties and things that go bump in the night.
reviews.author: Philip French

reviews.text: The polish belies the fact that The Conjuring's a sausage made from the ground-up leftovers of other movies. Said offcuts are fact based of course.
reviews.author: Ed Whitfield

reviews.text: The sound effects are the aural equivalent of a 21st century form of digital diarrhoea, guaranteed to leave the hairs on the back of your neck suffering from erectile dysfunction.
reviews.author: Graham Young

reviews.text: Wan is super-talented at delivering frissons and jumps, he just needs to take himself a bit more seriously.
reviews.author: David Cairns

reviews.text: Smart, stylish horror flick, though a standout more for its elegant performances than any original scares.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: A meticulously and ingeniously crafted scare machine.
reviews.author: Richard Edwards

reviews.text: The film may flaunt its true-story credentials for the sake of lurid immediacy but, like the best of its variety, it has a healthy understanding of its own silliness.
reviews.author: Guy Lodge

reviews.text: Wan's shocks are predictable but - yikes! - are they scary.
reviews.author: Henry Barnes

reviews.text: Here is a humdrum hunk of am-dram Gothic, lent prestige by a few specious avowals of its basis in a true exorcism case.
reviews.author: Nigel Andrews

reviews.text: Conjures up expertly timed scares and very little else.
reviews.author: Martyn Conterio

reviews.text: It stretches the truth far beyond the breaking point, but it is also creepy, scary and well-constructed.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: Wan's film is a sturdily built supernatural chiller, with next-to-no digital effects or gore, and it delivers its scares with a breezy lack of urgency.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Stirs up some seriously scary, supremely creep-ifying mojo. There's something about this movie that you'll swear is following you home.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: There are some top-notch creepy moments and the picture is crafted with real care but the denouement is underwhelming and my palms never really sweated.
reviews.author: Henry Fitzherbert

reviews.text: Hugely enjoyable, genuinely scary horror flick that provides a welcome throwback to classic 1970s chillers ...
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: A tense and exciting haunted house movie, The Conjuring relies on atmosphere rather than gore to serve up an entertaining slice of ghostie shenanigans with the simple ambition of scaring the bejesus out of viewers.
reviews.author: Catherine Bray

reviews.text: Slick, scary and with a sequel already on the way, The Conjuring doesn't reinvent the horror wheel but is still a frightener that's worth your time.
reviews.author: Lewis Bazley

reviews.text: Wan builds mounting dread with silence and suspense, lingering the camera unsettlingly long here, creaking a door there.
reviews.author: Cath Clarke

reviews.text: ...2013's horror film to beat. (Video review)
reviews.author: Adam Ross

reviews.text: Terrific and scary-as-hell horror movie more in the spirit of psychological classics like The Innocents or the original 1963 The Haunting.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: It's not just the furniture that creaks, but there are still some effective jolts.
reviews.author: Siobhan Synnot

reviews.text: Wan ... builds the many bumps in the night into a small Hitchcockian symphony of terror by way of long, eerie tracking shots, dramatic silences, and sudden scares that are frighteningly immersive.
reviews.author: Bruce Diones

reviews.text: Despite having a story lacking in depth, The Conjuring almost feels like a master class in conventional horror movie making, as though this is the archetype of the genre.
reviews.author: Stefan Pape

reviews.text: Though it frequently lapses into cliché, the real-life roots make it extra spine-tingling.
reviews.author: Stella Papamichael

reviews.text: Full of atmosphere and ghostly goodness, the only thing that doesn't seem to make any sense is the title.
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: There's very little in The Conjuring that couldn't have been achieved on film 40 years ago, which lends it a very authentic feel.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: It's really not much more frightening than, say, The Flintstones Meet Rockula and Frankenstone or Scooby-Doo on Zombie Island, but it's modestly elevated by James Wan's relatively restrained direction.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: What director James Wan does in "The Conjuring" is employ old-fashioned shocks - things that bump in the night, insinuations of nefarious spirits, even a furniture-banging exorcism - in creative and ultimately terrifying ways.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: ...there were moments where it seemed the entire theater was holding its breath. We were united in one feeling: terror.
reviews.author: Ian Buckwalter

reviews.text: The Conjuring is like the horror equivalent of a 'Long Island iced tea'; mixing stiff belts of haunted house, poltergeist and exorcism into a near perfect and potent cocktail.
reviews.author: Blake Howard

reviews.text: Wan, a director with an extensive resume in cinematic scare tactics, operates in his element here, opting not to push the horror envelope, but merely to refine it.
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: The Conjuring will have you shuddering with every creepy moment.
reviews.author: Lori Hoffman

reviews.text: I'm uh-scared, I'm uh-scared!
reviews.author: Bob Grimm

reviews.text: Old-style filmmaking makes this movie scarier than other recent horror films, simply because director Wan (Saw/Insidious) takes the time to actually develop suspense. By not using cheap trickery, he continually sends chills up our spine.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: A better than average horror movie sparked by excellent performances by the four leads.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: Sometimes a good horror film makes you chuckle.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: James Wan's 2004 breakthrough, Saw, was the definition of torture porn. His latest, on the other hand, is simply torture.
reviews.author: Rick Kisonak

reviews.text: I would happily watch it again, which is something I rarely say about horror films.
reviews.author: Jeff Bayer

reviews.text: The drip-feed of old tricks and a slow-drifting camera combine to stoke our expectation.
reviews.author: Kevin Harley

reviews.text: A skillful, well-crafted movie that nicely melds the horror material with strong characterization and a deeper-than-expected story. The Conjuring represents the horror genre at its best and most substantive.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: What more you could expect or want from a ghost story: it creeps, it crawls, it sneaks up on you and goes 'boo!', all without missing a beat or running out of steam.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: The film doesn't require belief in demonic possession or the supernatural to be effective. It reveals secrets only as needed, and gets under the collective skin of moviegoers by cleverly exploiting old-fashioned fear of the unknown.
reviews.author: Todd Jorgenson

reviews.text: This is a successful film thanks to Wan's unique vision and characters you can care about. Easily one of the best horror films I've seen in quite a while.
reviews.author: Austin Kennedy

reviews.text: The horror movie is artfully crafted from the first scares to the closing credits, with a bold retro vibe.
reviews.author: Peter Hartlaub

reviews.text: It's glorious and a reminder that the scares of a haunted house are visceral and, like Chucky, live on the cusp of childhood, frivolous and frightening.
reviews.author: Sara Maria Vizcarrondo

reviews.text: Wan's latest exercise in jump-scare theatre... better to call it "The Startling".
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: ... An old-school spookfest, a surprisingly restrained, moody picture ...
reviews.author: Greg Maki

reviews.text: Its climax reminds one of The Exorcist.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: The cast puts their all into the film, turning what could have been a cliché'd filled blood-fest into a modern horror gem.
reviews.author: Michael A. Smith

reviews.text: A character declares, 'God brought us together for a reason!' Too bad it was for this movie, another over-hyped horror flick rehashing a four-decade old storyline.
reviews.author: Clay Cane

reviews.text: As resistant as I am to spooky movies of all kinds, I do admire Wan's direction .... He realises all the potential in the drama, in the images and in the editing, managing to give us frequent chills
reviews.author: Andrew L. Urban

reviews.text: Dress warmly and take a friend - The Conjuring is a chilly and unnerving experience. Based on a true story, Saw director James Wan's slick horror film has all the elements to make your skin crawl
reviews.author: Louise Keller

reviews.text: The list of imagery "borrowed" from other films is lengthy. Director James Wan specializes in this sort of fare and his talented cast elevates the material above the dregs of the genre, which is an admittedly big and crowded basement.
reviews.author: Corey Hall

reviews.text: It's not rated 'R' because of gore, sex or foul language - the usual suspects. No, 'The Conjuring' is rated 'R' because its paranormal-based violence is so ... creepy.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: It will scare your underpants off.
reviews.author: Willie Waffle

reviews.text: Rather than gore, Wan goes for a more old-fashioned, character-based movie here, and, as a result, a treasure trove of typical haunting tricks seems fresh and terrifying once again.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: How about that? Someone conjured up a good ghost story!
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: A solid, dependably scary ghost tale.
reviews.author: Kelly Vance

reviews.text: This is a horror film where a pair of suddenly clapping hands gives you the heebie-jeebies, and Wan doesn't cheat with his jump scares.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: This isn't an instant classic, but it definitely reaffirms that Wan can do some interesting things within the horror genre.
reviews.author: Matthew Razak

reviews.text: Simply put: With simple, creative and very effective scare sequences, The Conjuring is the scariest movie of 2013 (so far).
reviews.author: Kofi Outlaw

reviews.text: An uncommonly intense and frightening experience.
reviews.author: Rene Rodriguez

reviews.text: Wan -- who made his reputation with the first Saw movie -- has a real understanding of the genre, and much of The Conjuring is well done.
reviews.author: Jay Stone

reviews.text: James Wan conjures up a truly paralyzing tale of supernatural terror with his retelling of Ed and Lorraine Warren's most disturbing case, creating scares through detailed and properly crafted horror storytelling - not a body count.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: In a summer of convoluted action films, the simplicity of a haunted house movie is actually kind of refreshing. Sometimes you want processed cheese, and this cheese is nicely processed.
reviews.author: Vincent Mancini

reviews.text: ... it surpasses the hallmarks of its genre with an actually dramatic storyline and all-around solid acting. Just don't think you can go see it alone.
reviews.author: Kate Erbland

reviews.text: It scared the living crap out of me. Only at the movies is that a compliment. So kudos to The Conjuring for putting fresh fire into the overworked haunted-house genre.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: Watching "The Conjuring" is like getting a tour of a haunted house attraction from someone that pushes, and pulls you through every room.
reviews.author: Simon Abrams

reviews.text: An extremely well-crafted piece of mainstream horror that offers a number of genuine scares.
reviews.author: Ethan Alter

reviews.text: Thank God I live in newish construction.
reviews.author: Erick Weber

reviews.text: Director James Wan does it again. First, it was the unexpected hit horror movie, "Insidious." Now, "The Conjuring" delivers the same scary bump-in-the-night thrills.
reviews.author: Paul Chambers

reviews.text: Director Wan takes a new pass at the creaky genre and comes up with exactly what you'd expect.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: While nothing new and playing up and off the various tricks previous horror films have used over the years, 'The Conjuring' still delivers enough effective scares and spooky material. (Full Parental Review also available)
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: With a sure-footed elegiac pace and a keen understanding that anticipation and what we don't see is sometimes more affecting than the payoff, "The Conjuring" plays like a loving throwback to cinema of the '70s.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: As "The Conjuring" progresses, the scares don't register beyond standard issue horror gotchas. They're as telegraphed as the musical cues alerting you something spooky is about to happen.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: The impact is in the suggested and the unseen, rather than the gory and grotesque - just as it is like the best classic horror films.
reviews.author: Cathy Jakicic

reviews.text: It isn't particularly deep, but it's a grab-your-seatmate good time at the haunted house.
reviews.author: Mike Russell

reviews.text: "The Conjuring'' depends more on its excellent cast and atmospheric direction than cheap gimmicks to raise hairs on the back of your neck. Which it does, quite frequently.
reviews.author: Lou Lumenick

reviews.text: [Wan] cuts The Conjuring into two halves -- an exhilarating haunted-house thriller and a grueling post-Exorcist horror film -- but they don't come back together in a living, breathing whole.
reviews.author: Michael Sragow

reviews.text: The Conjuring doesn't have the big special effects of its summer competition, but it is an old-fashioned scary movie that uses every dark corner as a source of scream-inducing frights. Don't see this movie by yourself.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: Unexpectedly fresh, alive, and vibrant - and wonderfully traumatizing.
reviews.author: Tirdad Derakhshani

reviews.text: This is an extremely effective, consistently creepy, and occasionally unnerving experience.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: One of the scarier haunted house/demon possession movies in recent years, it brings to mind '70s supernatural horror films such as The Exorcist with its stillness, steady build of suspense and handsome cinematography.
reviews.author: Claudia Puig

reviews.text: The dread gathers and surges while the blood scarcely trickles in "The Conjuring," a fantastically effective haunted-house movie.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: This is a director inspired by grand, gothic horror, more interested in long silences and swooping camera movements than torture porn or gruesome decapitations. The guy wants to wring you out.
reviews.author: Will Leitch

reviews.text: This saga of demonic possession deploys the full audio firepower of modern multiplexes, and does so with brain-battering frequency, like a ghostbusting version of a Japanese Taiko drum ensemble.
reviews.author: Joe Morgenstern

reviews.text: The Conjuring feels like someone chucked Poltergeist, Paranormal Activity, The Orphanage, Insidious and especially The Amityville Horror into a blender, then added a bit with a doll.
reviews.author: Dominic Corry

reviews.text: Wan builds suspense until it's almost unbearable, then adds a little more, just to make sure the audience is as terrified as the characters.
reviews.author: Loey Lockerby

reviews.text: What saves the movie is a surprisingly fine cast and deft direction from James Wan, the horror veteran who gave us "Saw."
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: The leads all perform with perfectly straight faces no matter how often the talk turns to witches and "inhuman spirits," which helps sell The Conjuring's fundamentally silly story. But Wan's direction seals the deal.
reviews.author: Keith Phipps

reviews.text: Mainstream horror at its best, James Wan continues to impress
reviews.author: Garry McConnachie

reviews.text: Again favoring tension over bedlam, Wan issues a similar but successful follow-up to Insidious, finding proper beats of fright and family to play in this throwback endeavor.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: The Conjuring finds director James Wan improving on his previous haunted-house yarn Insidious in just about every way possible.
reviews.author: Jason Buchanan

reviews.text: It never met a haunted house cliche it didn't like, but Wan mercilessly piles on the uncanny events, gradually escalating the pitch from creepy to freaky to utterly bananas.
reviews.author: Brian Juergens

reviews.text: It's a terrific throwback to more psychologically based horror.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: With its forked tongue planted loosely in cheek, this haunted-house flick is enjoyably retro in both style and substance.
reviews.author: Joe Williams

reviews.text: Solid horror film that pays hommage to the great character-driven horror classics of the sixties and seventies.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: Wan has gotten very good at crafting those creepy moments; now he just needs to apply them to a more interesting story.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: It's generic and lazy as storytelling, but this time there's almost enough playful camerawork to distract from the feeble conception.
reviews.author: Ben Sachs

reviews.text: The seen-it-all-before elements of this supernatural thriller directed by the filmmaker who gave us Saw, however, are more hoary than horrific. It might as well be retitled The Amityville Exorcist.
reviews.author: Steve Davis

reviews.text: The damned thing works you so well that you may even consider leaving halfway through, for fear you'll have a heart attack.
reviews.author: Bilge Ebiri

reviews.text: a well made horror film that can't be taken seriously. Oddly, while it's a much better effort than the director's last, "Insidious" was more genuinely eerie.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: A trim, effective haunted-house spook show, "The Conjuring" is both a throwback to early-'70s real estate shriekers like "The Amityville Horror" and a big-studio response to the "Paranormal Activity" found-footage genre.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: Creepily effective...the cinematic equivalent of a well-constructed spooky carnival attraction.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: Horror buffs will find [it] a highly satisfying, well-crafted film in a classical mode, with plenty of scares and very little gore.
reviews.author: Andrew O'Hehir

reviews.text: The poster for The Conjuring boasts "from the director of Saw and Insidious", which was a much wiser choice than "from the writers of The Reaping".
reviews.author: Steve Newton

reviews.text: Like a game of spot the cliche.
reviews.author: Matt Pais

reviews.text: James Wan's haunted-house saga is well-crafted, convincingly acted, surprisingly restrained and scary as hell.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: ...a truly creepy exercise. You may not believe in haunted houses, but you will while watching the movie.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: As an exercise in classical scare tactics, delivered through an escalating series of primo setpieces, The Conjuring is often supremely effective.
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: If I was to use a single word to describe The Conjuring, it would be "intense."
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: Wan masterfully tightens the vise on the audience's nerves, using mood and sound effects for shocks that never feel cheap (the harmless kids' game of hide-and-clap has never been so bloodcurdling).
reviews.author: Chris Nashawaty

reviews.text: The Conjuring gets under your skin, where the goosebumps are.
reviews.author: Steve Persall

reviews.text: "The Conjuring" wants Dan and Lorraine to seem like Indiana Jones-style hunters of the supernatural, but in this basic jolt-provider, they're as fascinating as the Jersey Devil.
reviews.author: Joe Neumaier

reviews.text: Delivers a steady stream of fist-clenching suspense and well-choreographed surprises.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: Could it be director James Wan was just a little too reverential? Because just when we couldn't need a chill down the spine more, this carefully made horror story delivers way too late in the game.
reviews.author: Joanna Langfield

reviews.text: James Wan proves himself to be moving quickly up the ranks of terror auteurs. The timing, pacing and character movement are outstanding. And it's scary as hell.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: The Conjuring is an unusually sturdy piece of haunted-house genre filmmaking.
reviews.author: Jake Coyle

reviews.text: Any hints of a smarter agenda serve to cloud the main one: "The Conjuring" has been engineered to freak you out.
reviews.author: Eric Kohn

reviews.text: A horror thriller that's silly yet scary enough to give you second thoughts if anyone suggests playing Hide 'n' Clap.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: It calls to mind films that understood that the less you saw, the spooker it got..It's as scary a film as I've seen in a long time.
reviews.author: Marshall Fine

reviews.text: Working with cinematographer John R. Leonetti and editor Kirk Morri, Wan carefully crafts each setpiece so that each visual punch has maximum impact to a nerve-shredding musical soundtrack from composer Joseph Bihara.
reviews.author: Charlie McCollum

reviews.text: It's not one of these one-note horror flicks hoping to make you jump; this KNOWS how scary it is and will get you by the end.
reviews.author: Mark Ellis

reviews.text: An "Amityville Horror" for a new century (and a far better movie than that 1979 hit), yet firmly rooted, without being slavish or self-conscious, in the visual language of 1970s filmmaking.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: I'm not the horror lover in Schmoes Know, but "The Conjuring" isn't just a great horror film, it's a great time at the movies.
reviews.author: Kristian Harloff

reviews.text: It takes a retro-fashioned winner like The Conjuring to remind us that if the creaky, old house ain't broke, don't fix it.
reviews.author: Joshua Rothkopf

reviews.text: So it could be a better horror movie. Big deal. Scary movies don't get much better than this.
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: Haunted-house tales don't come more imitative than The Conjuring, which doesn't emulate demonic-infestation and possession tales like The Amityville Horror and The Exorcist so much as operate as a veritable compendium of their myriad tropes.
reviews.author: Nick Schager

reviews.text: Boasting a stellar cast, a robust story and consistently energetic direction, The Conjuring is a true old fashioned ghost story, and a damn fine one at that.
reviews.author: Anthony O'Connor

reviews.text: Damned if director James Wan, the auteur of Saw's rusted-edge cruelty, isn't an ace with enjoyable spookhouse trap-springing.
reviews.author: Alan Scherstuhl

reviews.text: "The Conjuring" backs up its creaking floor and slamming door tropes with episodes of all-out terror to send its audience to bed with a worrisome feeling in the pit of their stomachs.
reviews.author: Cole Smithey

reviews.text: The most spine-tingling exorcist flick since, well, since The Exorcist!
reviews.author: Kam Williams

reviews.text: Loaded with nightmarish scenarios and an exceptional amount of character development. It's more than just a good scare; it's a truly thoughtful and all-consuming experience.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: Though The Conjuring claims to be based on a true story, in truth it's based on every horror film that's come before it.
reviews.author: Ed Gonzalez

reviews.text: Australian-trained director James Wan...continues to exhibit growth as a filmmaker with a keen eye for genre scares; if he can hone his ear to weeding out tinny dialogue, he will likely make a great film one day.
reviews.author: Simon Foster

reviews.text: All the contorting girls and pea-soup vomit in the world can hardly compete with a blood-stained sheet and a well-placed doll.
reviews.author: William Goss

reviews.text: Thoughtful where its competition is glib, featuring substantive and relatable characters, and steadily-paced where most feel lackadaisical, Wan has made a truly great movie. And I'm only talking about the parts that I saw from between my fingers.
reviews.author: Todd Gilchrist

reviews.text: You've seen it before, you'll see it again.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: Taut and effective edge-of-the-seat horror, delivered with style and an especially haunting performance by Vera Farmiga.
reviews.author: Sheri Linden

reviews.text: While The Conjuring is incredibly well made there's little we haven't seen before.
reviews.author: Henry Northmore

reviews.text: Just a good old-fashioned scare, if you get scared by that sort of thing.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: A sensationally entertaining old-school freakout and one of the smartest, most viscerally effective thrillers in recent memory.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: The Conjuring is a masterclass in absolute terror that's destined to become a classic within the genre.
reviews.author: Steve

reviews.text: The Conjuring doesn't try to reinvent the tropes of horror movies, whether it's ghosts or demons or exorcisms, but Fred Astaire didn't invent tap-dancing, either.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: [The Conjuring] will have the hair on your arms standing straight up, and your brain screaming in excitement!
reviews.author: Brad Miska

reviews.text: Rattling the nerves while drawing out its palpable sense of dread, "The Conjuring" is a proudly old-fashioned horror movie that tells its story with sophistication and care.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: ... it is confident, it is beautifully acted, and when it gets serious about being scary, it is remarkably tense and terrifying.
reviews.author: Drew McWeeny

synopsis: In 1970, paranormal investigators and demonologists Lorraine (Vera Farmiga) and Ed (Patrick Wilson) Warren are summoned to the home of Carolyn (Lili Taylor) and Roger (Ron Livingston) Perron. The Perrons and their five daughters have recently moved into a secluded farmhouse, where a supernatural presence has made itself known. Though the manifestations are relatively benign at first, events soon escalate in horrifying fashion, especially after the Warrens discover the house's macabre history.
